Bryan Jaybee
Freelance photojournalist interested in conflict and human interest stories. Currently documenting the everyday norm inside Africa’s largest slum.
Mar 31

Teenage Moms of Kibera

In Kibera, the largest slum of Africa, located in Nairobi, Kenya, 25 percent of girls aged 15–19 years have already given birth due to lack of empowerment and lack of education about premarital sexual relations. The consequences of these early pregnancies has led to approximately 30 percent of the girls dropping out of school in Kibera.

They are rejected by the community and driven away from home by their families. Some have even resorted to prostitution as a result. Despite several efforts made by non-governmental organizations to bring support to the most serious cases of these teen mothers, the majority of them are not helped and are always on their own.

As someone who was born and raised in Kibera by a young mother, I have witnessed so much struggle in such an environment and understand the feeling and importance of a mom in a family. My motivation to tell the stories of these teen mothers is to call for more attention on the real lives and situations of this marginal group and extend the discussion further to several other vital social issues such as empowerment and education.

Lucy Atieno is 19 years old and sitting beside her is Scholes Timberline, her only child, whom she had when she was 17 years old. She’s one of the many teen moms in Kibera with so much potential never realized, trapped in a circle of poverty, crime and drug abuse. Inside her mud-walled house, there are two wooden beds arranged at right angle positions with a chair adjacent to the door. At one corner there are bags of clothes, lots of boxes and a kitchen set up next to the window.

Why two beds? I ask. One was for my mom, the other one is for me and Scholes. My mums don’t stay here nowadays. She got a ‘sponsor’. I stay here with six of my friends, she reveals.

Another group of ladies emerge from the corridors leading to Atieno’s house. They are talking loudly and it appears they are arguing about something. They enter the house and throw themselves in the beds. They are Atieno’s friends — Amam, Evonne, Salome, and Irene. I am told all of them are mothers, except Evonne whose child died of malaria at six months.

There’s a plot for tonight in town, Evonne says. A plot refers to a plan, mostly something good. The girls are excited. They take some clothes and soap to the shower outside , not far from the house. This is also their hangout joint. Sometimes they sit here the whole day, plaiting their hair, teasing men who pass by and asking them for money.

There’s another group of women who sit at the verandah near the shower. They look much older and are in charge of the public toilet and washrooms. The girls are trouble and we don’t want to associate with them. They have no respect, one of the women says to another woman — possibly a newbie in the area.

Nobody wants cold water. A shower is 10 shillings for hot water and 5 shillings for cold water. One after another goes for the hot water. Seems like today you have so much money, jokes one of the women amidst laughter from the others. Atieno picks up a container, and pours cold water through an opening in the shower to a friend who’s bathing. They like this game a lot and it goes and on until everyone is clean and fresh.

Back in the house, the girls are looking for clothes to wear for tonight’s plot. Their best attires are separated from the other ones so they’re easy to find. Makeup is key and they all want to look good. Holding a tiny mirror, Atieno constantly admires herself while applying foundation onto her face.

Are you going to leave Scholes alone when you go out tonight?, I ask
I will leave him at my cousin’s place.
What about the father?
He’s not here. I don’t even remember when we talked last. We are not together anymore.

As the evening fades, two more ladies enter the house. One is chewing miraa (another name for khat — a shrub whose leaves are chewed as a mild stimulant) and carrying a black polythene bag with paraphernalia that accompany the miraa. She removes some tablets from the bag and excitement from the girls fills the room. There’s a lot of commotion.

These are taptap , they make you go high, Atieno says.

Taptap is a cheap clinical drug that makes one high upon consumption. It can easily be bought over the counter by those who use it and know what it is.

It’s a routine, before stepping out, a dose of taptap is a must. One cannot simply go out on a sober mind. It’s clubbing, not a birthday party, one of the girls adds.

They swallow the taptap. Some take one and others take two, but it all depends on your level of addiction. At this point, there’s too much noise. They talk of their own stories. Seems they are high already.

Sharon Mbone, 17, has two kids. One-year-old Herine and 2-month-old Romain Shane. She’s married to her long-term boyfriend, 22-year-old Terry. Her first pregnancy was unplanned, and so was the second, but she doesn’t regret anything. She was 15 when she met Terry. She was brought from upcountry to work as house help in Nairobi because there was no money to take her to secondary school.

With two kids already she doesn’t want to go back to school, but would like to join a vocation center and train as a tailor. Her second pregnancy was met with a lot of criticism and gossip. She knows very little and Terry’s sister Valentine took care of her until she delivered. Her doctor was shocked after finding out how old she was and that this was her second child. She was promised a 10-year dose of family planning three months after giving birth, but she’s reluctant. She says her body doesn’t respond well to it.

Valerie, Helishia, Sharz and Salome all have children who are two years and younger. All are staying with their parents and most are single mothers. Valerie’s child is named Triza Maya, a name that was given by her mother whom, despite all the circumstances, had to accept the fact that her teenage daughter was pregnant.

She used to say: “Go back to the person that made you pregnant,” but nowadays she’s cool with it. Next year she’s going back to school and her mother will be taking care of her little baby girl.

Helishia, 20, now an aspiring journalist, also lives with her mother and helps her with her small grocery business. She did her final high school examination only a few days after giving birth.

Our relationship was on contract. He got me pregnant, we finished school and that was it. I have nothing to do with him. He doesn’t add up in my life anyway, Helishia tells me.

Salome, 18, one of Atieno’s good friends, also stays with her mother in a tiny room in Soweto West, Kibera. Her child, Tyler, is approaching two years and Salome doesn’t want to talk about her relationship with the father. I bought him in the supermarket, she jokes. My mom is my everything and at times I feel like Tyler is her last born.

Her mom comes in, serves tea and we talk amidst sips. Salome looks innocent here, unlike when she’s with the other girls at Atieno’s house. I ask what her plans are. She is an artist and can paint very well, but she also wants to learn to be a hairdresser.

Shamzie Mohamed and Immaculate Achieng are both pregnant. Shamzie is expecting her second baby. Her first child is in the upcountry with her parents and her pregnancies are from two different fathers.

Giving birth is not the problem. The problem is raising the child, she says.

Sixteen-year-old Immaculate is new to all this. This is her first pregnancy. Immaculate is naïve and shy, and that makes me feel sorry for her. In just a few months, she’ll be an addition to the growing statistic of teen moms in Kibera.

Molly gave birth when she was 16 and got married to a man who is 46. She’s happy with her marriage, despite all the factors. Her mom was furious.

Back in Atieno’s house, two men come and stand at the door. They ask for Irene, one of the girls. They talk about a deal that didn’t go very well—looks like a bad deal from their reactions. They leave, and I’m told one of the men is Irene’s barongo (a term they use to refer to men who give them money, but not sexual favors). It’s their code. One must never sleep with a barongo. They are only in the relationship for the money.

Barongo are very stingy people. If you discover that they begin to know what’s happening, then you just leave them, Evonne says.

But Irene has a sponsor, Evonne insists. In this context, a sponsor refers to older men often dating young ladies — giving them gifts in exchange for sexual favors. Irene doesn’t like this kind of talk and so she hides her head into the blanket, face down.

All text and images © Bryan Jaybee

Bryan was one of 12 participants selected for the 2016 Masterclass East Africa, the second in the World Press Photo Foundation’s series of satellite masterclasses based on the formula of the annual Joop Swart Masterclass for the world’s most talented upcoming visual journalists.
